abstract: <jats:p> What do recent advances in economic geography teach us about the spatial distribution of economic activity? We show that the equilibrium distribution of economic activity can be determined simply by the intersection of labor supply and demand curves. We discuss how to estimate these curves and highlight the importance of global geography—the connections between locations through the trading network—in determining how various policy relevant changes to geography shape the spatial economy. </jats:p>
title: Economic Activity across Space: A Supply and Demand Approach

affiliation.name: Treb Allen is Distinguished Associate Professor of Economics and Globalization, Dartmouth College, Hanover, New Hampshire.
Costas Arkolakis is Professor of Economics, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut. .
